Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Interdisciplinary Nano Tools Course at the University of Rhode Island

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: Interdisciplinary Nano Tools Course at the University of Rhode Island", at the University of Rhode Island (URI) under the direction of Dr. Geoffrey D. Bothun, will focus on the instrumentation tools used to characterize physical and chemical properties of nanomaterials. The rationale behind focusing on Nano Tools is that instrumentation is broadly applicable to nanomaterials of varying composition and geometry, and, by first learning the tools, students can better grasp nanomaterial characterization that will feed into their understanding of eventual applications. Nano Tools will provide basic principles of operation and hands-on experience in dynamic light scattering (DLS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM).

Nano Tools will develop nanotechnology concept competences and professional skills in undergraduate students within STEM majors at URI. The new course will be open to junior and senior students and available as a professional elective course for all five URI engineering majors: Chemical; Civil and Environmental; Electrical, Computer, and Biomedical; Mechanical, Industrial, and Systems; and Ocean Engineering in conformity with the norms of the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology (ABET). The pre-requisites are relaxed and clearly defined so that more STEM students can enroll into the course. The course will also complement two other nanocourses that are currently offered at URI, and will provide a basis for the development of a future nanotechnology minor. This will be the first course of its kind offered at URI, and will provide the basis for an interdisciplinary nanotechnology minor and/or certificate program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanotechnology is an interdisciplinary STEM field and a driving force for economic development.  Many companies in areas spanning energy, transportation, construction materials, food and agriculture, and pharmaceutics are employing and actively developing new products containing nanotechnologies. The goal of this NSF Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education project was to develop a new ‘Nano Tools’ course at the University of Rhode Island to train a cohort of undergraduate students across STEM disciplines that are prepared for future nanotechnology-based jobs and advanced training in higher education. EGR450X: Nano Tools was offered for three semesters and a total of thirty students received hands-on training on state-of-the-art nanotechnology instrumentation or Nano Tools. A key objective was to directly connect fundamental and applied aspects of nanotechnology so students would gain a deeper understanding of how nanotechnologies are impacting commercial products and how the properties of nanomaterials are different for different materials, sizes, and shapes. The laboratory training was reinforced through intensive independent research projects guided by faculty mentors. Through these projects, student teams developed plans for materials synthesis and characterization on applied projects with commercial relevance. In addition to student technical training and testing a new approach to nanotechnology undergraduate education, this project fostered peer-to-peer learning through laboratories and problem-based learning, enhanced student written and oral communication skills, and built student-faculty and faculty-faculty collaboration.
